user_preference: Write as a short modern kids' nonfiction paragraph for age 7. Keep the main logic and contrast from the Greek, but prefer one clear plain phrasing per idea. Avoid formal translation wording and avoid cutesy substitute nouns. Recast awkward structure freely.

paragraphs.greek: εἴη μὲν οὖν ἡμῖν ἐκκαθαιρόμενον λόγῳ τὸ μυθῶδες ὑπακοῦσαι καὶ λαβεῖν ἱστορίας ὄψιν, ὅπου δ᾽ ἂν αὐθαδῶς τοῦ πιθανοῦ περιφρονῇ καὶ μὴ δέχηται τὴν πρὸς τὸ εἰκὸς μῖξιν, εὐγνωμόνων ἀκροατῶν δεησόμεθα καὶ πρᾴως τὴν ἀρχαιολογίαν προσδεχομένων.

reference_translations.dryden_clough: May I therefore succeed in purifying fable, making it submit to reason so as to assume the face of history. Where it cannot be reduced to any probable likeness, and refuses to admit any element of the possible, I shall beg my readers to be indulgent to antiquity in its records.
reference_translations.perrin: May I therefore succeed in purifying Fable, making her submit to reason and take on the semblance of History. But where she obstinately disdains to make herself credible, and refuses to admit any element of probability, I shall pray for kindly readers, and such as receive with indulgence the tales of antiquity.

translation_step.observations: a) Plain restatement for kids: I hope to clean up myths with reason so they look like true history, but if myths stubbornly won't mix with what's believable, I'll ask for kind readers to gently accept ancient tales. b) Source-close sketch: May it be ours for the mythical, purified by reason, to obey and take history's appearance; but wherever it arrogantly scorns the plausible and refuses mix with the probable, we shall beg understanding hearers who mildly receive the ancient records. c) Candidates: 1. Reason will scrub myths clean to seem historical; stubborn ones need patient kids for old stories. 2. Let's make myths logical like history—but beg kindness for the unbelievable ancient bits (breaks syntax). Focus: simplify contrast, one phrasing per idea, kid-plain dignified.
translation_step.translation: I hope to use reason to clean up the myths and make them look like true history. But if some myths stubbornly refuse to seem believable or blend with what's likely, I'll ask for kind readers who patiently accept these ancient stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong adaptation for 7-year-olds: captures core hope-contrast logic plainly without dropping relations, flows naturally, and uses kid-level modern English; minor tweaks needed for maximally direct outcome phrasing.
judgment_step.strengths: Preserves exact contrast (rationalized myths as history vs. indulgent readers for stubborn parts); one clear phrasing per idea with merged flow; simple sentences and words like 'clean up' and 'stubbornly refuse' suit kids' nonfiction without cutesy slang; no abstract chains or translationese.
judgment_step.issues: 'Blend with what's likely' slightly indirect and vague for age 7 (better as direct 'mix in real possibilities'); 'seem believable' repeats idea of 'look like true history' indirectly; 'patiently accept' borrows indulgent tone from refs instead of fresh plain 'forgive old tales' phrasing.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Change to: 'I hope to use reason to clean up myths and make them look like real history. But if some myths stubbornly won't mix with real possibilities or sound true, I'll need kind readers who forgive these old stories.' This uses direct outcome verbs ('mix... sound true'), swaps 'patiently accept' for plain 'forgive', keeps length short.

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to use reason to clean up the myths and make them look like true history. But if some myths stubbornly refuse to seem believable or blend with what's likely, I'll ask for kind readers who patiently accept these ancient stories.

translation_step.observations: a) Plain restate for kids: I want to use clear thinking to fix up myths so they look like true stories from history. But if some myths won't play nice with what makes sense, I hope readers are kind and okay with old tales. b) Source-close: May it be ours, purifying the mythical by argument to obey and take history's appearance; but wherever arrogantly it scorns the believable and rejects mix with the likely, we'll need sensible hearers gently welcoming the ancient inquiry. c) Candidates: 1. Use logic to tidy myths into history shape; stubborn ones need patient readers for ancient stuff. 2. Hope reason cleans myths to look real; if they refuse believability mix, ask kind folks to indulge old stories. 3. Break syntax: Clean myths with reason for history look. Seek nice readers for defiant ancient tales that skip probability.
translation_step.translation: I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths and make them look like real history. But if some stubbornly refuse to mix with what's believable, I'll ask for kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong iteration that nails the kid-friendly plainness and contrast while staying faithful; minor tweaks needed for zero personification hints and maximally direct phrasing.
judgment_step.strengths: Preserves core hope-to-purify contrast and request for kind readers without dropping logic; uses one clear plain phrase per idea (e.g., 'clean up myths and make them look like real history'); excellent flow in two short sentences; all vocabulary at age-7 level with natural modern rhythm.
judgment_step.issues: Mild personification in 'some stubbornly refuse' (source treats myth element as subject but kids nonfiction prefers direct 'myths won't fit'); 'clean up' slightly indirect for purifying to history face (could specify outcome more plainly); 'clear thinking' good but edges bookish vs. everyday 'reason'; no core drops but 'these ancient stories' borrows ref phrasing vaguely.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Replace 'I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths' with 'I hope to use reason to strip myths from stories so they look like true history'; change 'But if some stubbornly refuse to mix with what's believable' to 'But if some myths won't blend with what's likely'; swap 'I'll ask for kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories' to 'we'll need patient readers who kindly accept old tales'; ensure single short paragraph.

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths and make them look like real history. But if some stubbornly refuse to mix with what's believable, I'll ask for kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories.

translation_step.observations: a) Kid-friendly restate: I want to fix myths with smart thinking to make them seem like true stories from history. But if myths won't mix with real possibilities, I need nice readers who are patient with ancient tales. b) Source-close: May we purify mythical with reason, hear/take history's look; but where it arrogantly scorns plausible and rejects likely mix, need understanding hearers who mildly receive antiquities. c) Candidates: 'Use logic to tidy myths into history shape, but stubborn ones need forgiving kids for old legends.' (breaks syntax); 'Reason cleans myths to history-look; implausible ones beg patient ancient-story fans.' Prioritize dignity, plain outcomes: tweak prev to sharper contrast, drop 'some' for directness, ensure one phrasing/idea flows naturally without personification.
translation_step.translation: I hope to use clear reasoning to clean up myths and make them look like real history. But if some stubbornly refuse to blend with what's believable, I'll need kind readers who patiently accept these ancient stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong iteration: faithful to core logic/contrast, highly readable for age 7 with plain phrasing, modern and direct without translationese or cutesy elements.
judgment_step.strengths: Captures purification via reason into history semblance; preserves exact contrast of stubborn refusal vs. need for indulgent readers; one clear phrasing per idea (cleanup to history; refusal to blend; kind patient acceptance); short sentences flow naturally; kid-level vocab like 'clean up,' 'stubbornly refuse,' 'believable,' 'ancient stories' feels like modern nonfiction.
judgment_step.issues: 'Some' is vague pronoun (refers to myths but not explicit, risks kid confusion); 'clean up' slightly casual vs. dignified plain alternative like 'clear out'; 'patiently accept' interprets 'πρᾴως προσδεχομένων' as patient when plain 'gently welcome' fits better; minor abstraction in 'blend with what's believable' when direct 'mix in real possibilities' sharpens for kids.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Change to: 'I hope to use reasoning to clear out myths and make them seem like true history. But if some myths stubbornly refuse to mix in anything believable, I'll need kind readers who gently welcome these ancient stories.' Explicit 'some myths'; 'clear out' for dignified plainness; 'seem like true history' nods to 'ὄψιν' semblance without formality; 'mix in anything believable' direct outcome phrasing; 'gently welcome' plain for 'πρᾴως προσδεχομένων'.

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to use clear reasoning to clean up myths and make them look like real history. But if some stubbornly refuse to blend with what's believable, I'll need kind readers who patiently accept these ancient stories.

translation_step.observations: a) Kid-friendly restate: I want to fix myths with clear thinking to make them seem like true history, but if some won't mix with real possibilities, I need patient readers okay with old tales. b) Source-close: May we purify mythical with reason, obey and grasp history's look; but where it arrogantly scorns plausible and rejects likely mix, need sensible hearers gently welcoming antiquities. c) Candidates: 'Use logic to scrub myths clean for history's face. Stubborn ones? Beg kind eyes for ancient lore.' (breaks syntax); 'Clean myths via reason into history shape, or plead for indulgent antique fans.'; 'Reason blends myths to facts; unblendable need forgiving crowd.' Prior: Refine prev for explicit refs (myths as actor), direct outcomes, dignified plainness no chains.
translation_step.translation: I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths and make them look like true history. But if some stubbornly refuse to mix in anything believable, I'll need kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong iteration: faithful to core logic and contrast, highly readable and modern for 7-year-olds, with natural plain phrasing that prioritizes user prompt over literalism.
judgment_step.strengths: Captures wish for rational purification of myths into history-like form and sharp contrast needing indulgent readers; uses direct kid-level verbs like 'clean up' and 'look like' instead of abstract nouns; short sentences flow effortlessly as nonfiction para; no cutesy nouns, no translationese chains, no borrowed ref phrasing.
judgment_step.issues: 'Clear thinking' slightly abstracts 'logō' when 'reason' or plain 'logic' would be simpler for age 7; 'some stubbornly refuse' vaguely personifies without naming 'myths,' risking pronoun confusion despite context; 'patiently welcome' dignifies but could plainify to 'nicely accept' for max kid directness without dropping indulgence.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Replace 'use clear thinking to clean up' with 'use reason to clean up'; specify 'some myths stubbornly refuse'; swap 'patiently welcome these ancient stories' to 'nicely accept these old stories'; merge into single flowing para if possible: 'I hope to use reason to clean up myths and make them look like true history. But if some myths stubbornly refuse to mix in anything believable, I'll need kind readers who nicely accept these old stories.'

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths and make them look like true history. But if some stubbornly refuse to mix in anything believable, I'll need kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories.

translation_step.observations: a) Plain restate for kids: I want to fix myths with smart thinking so they look like true history stories. But if some myths won't make any sense, I hope readers are nice and enjoy the old tales anyway. b) Source-close: May we purify mythical stuff with reason, hear it, and give it history's look; but where it arrogantly ignores believable and rejects mix with probable, need understanding hearers who mildly accept ancient lore. c) Candidates: 'Clean myths with logic to match history's look. Stubborn ones need patient kids for old stories.' (breaks syntax); 'Use reason to make myths believable like history, but beg kind readers for the impossible bits from antiquity.' Prior fixes: More natural flow, explicit refs (myths as actor), plain outcomes like 'seem like history'.
translation_step.translation: I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths and make them look like true history. But if some stubbornly refuse to blend in anything believable, I'll need kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong iteration: highly readable and modern for 7-year-olds, faithful to core logic/contrast without Greek-shaped phrasing or abstractions; minor faithfulness tweak needed for plural 'us' and precise 'probable likeness' intent.
judgment_step.strengths: Direct plain phrasing per idea ('clean up myths' for purifying, 'blend in anything believable' for mixing with eikos); excellent flow with short sentences; age-appropriate vocabulary (no cutesy/slang, plain/dignified); preserves contrast without simplification loss; natural modern kids' nonfiction tone.
judgment_step.issues: 'I hope'/'I'll need' shifts source optative plural 'for us' (ἡμῖν) to singular first-person, slightly diluting shared authorial voice; 'clear thinking' abstracts λόγῳ (reason) when plainer 'reason' fits kids' level; 'true history' undersells 'semblance/face of history' (ὄψιν ἱστορίας) as visual/appearance match.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Change to 'We hope to use reason to clean up myths and make them look like real history.' for plural voice and simpler 'reason'; tweak second sentence to 'But if some stubbornly won't mix in anything probable, we'll need kind readers who welcome ancient tales with patience.' to hit 'probable likeness' directly and vary 'patiently welcome' for flow; ensure single paragraph format.

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to use clear thinking to clean up myths and make them look like true history. But if some stubbornly refuse to blend in anything believable, I'll need kind readers who patiently welcome these ancient stories.

translation_step.observations: a) Kid-friendly restate: I want to clean myths with smart thinking to make them look like real history. But if they won't add anything believable, I need nice readers okay with old stories. b) Source-close: May we purify mythical with reason, obey and take history's look; but where arrogantly scorns plausible and rejects likely mix, need sensible hearers gently receiving ancient lore. c) Candidates: 1. Reason cleans myths into history shape; stubborn ones need patient kids for old tales. 2. I hope logic turns myths historical--if not, kind readers please for ancient bits. 3. Break syntax: Clean myths to history via reason. For unblendable defiant myths: seek gentle ancient-story fans. Prior fix: Sharpen direct outcomes (purify success vs. need indulgence), plain verbs over abstracts.
translation_step.translation: I hope to use reason to clean up myths and give them the look of true history. But if some stubbornly reject anything believable and refuse to mix in what's likely, I'll need kind readers who welcome ancient stories with patience.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong iteration: faithful to core logic and contrast, highly readable and modern for 7-year-olds with plain phrasing; minor clarity tweak needed for subject reference.
judgment_step.strengths: Captures purification hope and stubborn refusal contrast directly; uses simple outcome phrasing ('clean up myths and give them the look') over abstract chains; flows naturally as short kids' nonfiction; plain vocab like 'true history' and 'kind readers' fits age 7 without cutesy or bookish tone.
judgment_step.issues: 'Some' mildly unclear as pronoun for myths (could confuse young readers); slight redundancy in 'anything believable' and 'what's likely' (both echo 'plausible'); 'true history' good but 'look of true history' could tighten to 'look like real history' for even plainer kid flow.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Change 'But if some stubbornly reject...' to 'But if those myths stubbornly refuse anything believable...'; merge 'anything believable and refuse to mix in what's likely' to 'and won't blend in anything likely'; swap 'true history' to 'real history'; end with 'who patiently welcome ancient stories' for tighter parallel.

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to use reason to clean up myths and give them the look of true history. But if some stubbornly reject anything believable and refuse to mix in what's likely, I'll need kind readers who welcome ancient stories with patience.

final_agent_versions.sequential: I hope to use reason to fix myths and make them seem like real history. But if some myths won't fit with what's possible or sound true, I'll need kind readers to forgive those old stories.

final_synthesis.final_translation: I hope to use reason to fix myths and make them seem like real history. But if some myths won't fit with what's possible or sound true, I'll need kind readers to forgive those old stories.
final_synthesis.justification: Simplified 'clean up' to 'fix', 'stubbornly won't mix' to 'won't fit'; smoothed structure for natural kid-friendly flow while keeping contrast, hope modality, and reader plea intact.

polish.notes: Simplified 'clean up' to 'fix', 'stubbornly won't mix' to 'won't fit'; smoothed structure for natural kid-friendly flow while keeping contrast, hope modality, and reader plea intact.

final_translation: I hope to use reason to fix myths and make them seem like real history. But if some myths won't fit with what's possible or sound true, I'll need kind readers to forgive those old stories.
